citation.article-title: Treponema socranskii sp. nov., Treponema socranskii subsp. socranskii subsp. nov. Treponema socranskii subsp. buccale subsp. nov., and Treponema socranskii subsp. paredis subsp. nov. isolated from human periodontia

p.s: Description of Treponema socranskii sp. nov.
Treponema socranskii (so.cranśki.i. N.L. gen. n. socranskii named for Sigmund S. Socransky, Forsyth Dental Center)
Treponema socranskii (homology groups A1, A2, and K) is an obligately anaerobic motile helically coiled treponeme (Fig. 1).
Electron photomicrographs of cultures in the logarithmic phase of growth show that there is one periplasmic flagellum originating from each end of the cell.
The periplasmic flagella overlap in the center region of the cell, giving a “1-2-1” relationship.
The cells are 6 to 15 μm long and 0.16 to 0.18 μm wide.
They have tapered ends with a slight bend or “hook” at one or both ends of the cell.
The cells form coccoid bodies in the late stationary growth phase.
Cells in broth cultures have both rotational and translational movement.
Serpentine movement of cells can be seen by dark-field microscopy of cultures grown in a semisolid medium.
Colonies.
Colonies usually appear in OTI agar in 7 to 10 days.
The colonies grow into the agar, are white and translucent, and often have slightly denser centers.
The edges of the colonies may be entire or irregular.
The colonies spread and become larger after extended incubation.
Cultural and growth characteristics. T . socranskii grows only in media containing a fermentable carbohydrate and either rumen fluid (20 to 30%) or a mixture of short-chain fatty acids (3, 16).
Serum is not required.
The optimum growth temperature is 37°C.
There is only slight growth at 25 or 42°C.
Broth cultures become turbid with a slightly granular sediment in 3 to 4 days.
Biochemical reactions and fermentation products.
The phenotypic characteristics of representative strains of T . socranskii are shown in Table 3.
The majority of the strains ferment glucose, with a final pH ranging from 5.1 to 5.9.
A few strains belonging to T. socranskii subsp. buccale do not produce a pH below 6.0 when they are grown in glucose-containing broth.
These cultures have a pH range of 6.2 to 6.7.

Inulin, lactose, melizitose, melibiose, cellobiose, salicin, D-sorbitol, glycerol, amygdalin, adonitol, dulcitol, i-erythritol, inositol, and D-mannitol are not fermented, as indicated by only a slight change in the pH of the medium.
Hydrogen sulfide is produced in SIM medium (BBL) supplemented with rumen fluid by all but 1 of 32 strains tested.
None of the strains studied produces catalase, peroxidase, indole, or acetylmethylcarbinol.
Esculin is not hydrolyzed.
Hydrogen gas is not detected by gas chromatography of samples taken from the atmosphere above the broth medium in rubber-stoppered tubes.
The major acid fermentation products of all strains grown in PY-glucose-rumen fluid broth are acetic, lactic, and succinic acids.
Trace amounts of formic acid occasionally can be found.
The strains produce an average of 8 mM lactic acid (range, 3 to 16 mM), 6.5 mM acetic acid (range, 2.6 to 10.4 mM), and 3 mM succinic acid (range, 1 to 6.5 mM).
Habitat. T. socranskii is associated with human gingival crevices and gingival sulci of patients with periodontal disease and experimental gingivitis and in people with healthy gingivae.

It is the most frequently isolated treponeme and is usually the most numerous organism among the cultivable treponemes in either supragingival or subgingival samples. T . socranskii subsp. socranskii and T . socranskii subsp. buccale are more common in these sites than T. socranskii subsp. paredis.
G+C content.
The G+C content of the DNA is 50.5 ± 2 mol% (thermal denaturation method) for selected strains and 52 mol% (thermal denaturation method) for the type strain.
Type strain.
The type strain is strain ATCC 35536 (= VPI DR56BRIII6), which was isolated from a subgingival sample
from a patient with severe periodontal disease.
